document.docAuthor: Padilla-Gil, Dora Nancy & Moreira, Felipe Ferraz Figueiredo
document.docTitle: Paravelia daza Padilla-Gil & Moreira, 2011, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Paravelia Breddin, 1898 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Veliidae) from Colombia, with a key to Colombian Paravelia species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Paravelia Breddin, 1898 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Veliidae) from Colombia, with a key to Colombian Paravelia species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype , apt 3 , allotype apt Ƥ: COLOMBIA , Departamento Nariño, Municipio Pasto, Daza ,
30 .VI. 2009
, leg. D.N. Padilla & O. Arcos ( ICN ). Paratypes , same data as holotype , 10 apt 3, 10 apt Ƥ ( ICN ), 15 apt 3, 15 apt Ƥ (PSO-CZ), 4 apt 3, 5 apt Ƥ (CP). Nariño, Tangua, Las Piedras,
24 .VI. 2009
, leg. D.N. Padilla 1 apt 3, 1 apt Ƥ (PSO-CZ).

Additional material. COLOMBIA , Departamento Nariño, Municipio Pasto, Daza ,
12 .X.2009
, 20 apt 3, 16 apt Ƥ. Nariño, Pasto, Corregimiento Mocondino, Vereda Dolores,
18 .XI.2009
, 2 apt 3, 2 apt Ƥ. Nariño, Tangua, Las Piedras,
16 .XI.2009
, 7 apt 3, 10 apt Ƥ, all leg. D.N. Padilla & O. Arcos (PSO-CZ).

caption.paragraph: FIGURES 1–2. P. d a z a , dorsal habitus. 1, female, 2, male. Scale 1mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Apterous male (
Fig. 2
). Length 9.2 , maximum width 2.16 . Head longer than wide (L/W: 1.44 / 1.16 ), bearing impressed median longitudinal line flanked by 2 ( 1 + 1 ) oblique rows of small lateral impressions (
Fig. 3
MI). Eyes prominent, bearing in adults and nymphs a short ocular seta inserted between the ommatidia on the posterior part of each eye (
Figs. 3–6
). Ocelli absent. Head bearing a pair of dorsal pits, near the corner of each eye (
Fig. 3
, DI ). Antenniferous tubercles well-defined (
Fig. 4
). Anteclypeus and ventral lobes of head prominent (
Fig. 3
, AC, VL).

Antenna subflagelliform, the two basal segments relatively long and the two apical segments rather slender, bearing numerous erect hairs. Length of antennomeres I–IV: 1.30 , 1.08 , 0.88 , 1.08 . Rostrum 4 -segmented, relatively long, reaching mesosternum; third article about 4 times longer than I–II combined (
Fig. 4
). Ventral region of head with a pair of distinct longitudinal ridges (
Fig. 5
, r); the posterior margin bearing two short and slender apodemes on each side (
Fig. 4
, OA).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 3. P. d a z a . Head capsule in anterodorsal view, antennae removed. Scale 0.025 mm. (AC: Anteclypeus, Ct: cephalic trichobothrium, DI: dorsal indentation of head, MI: median impressed line of head, VL: ventral lobe of head).

FIGURES 4–6. P. d a z a . 4–5. Head capsule, 4, lateral view (OA: occipital apodeme); 5, ventral view; labium removed (r: ventral ridge); 6, first instar nymph, dorsal view with appendages removed. Scale 0.025 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Anterior portion of prothorax with a distinct collar. Pronotal lobe (
Fig. 7
, PL) large, arched in the middle and posteriorly extended, covering mesonotum and most of metanotum (
Fig. 2
). Pronotum (L/W: 1.92 / 1.96 ), bearing a longitudinal medial carina; anterior margin with a line of punctuations behind head vertex, prolonged on sides and venter of prothorax. Pronotal surface uneven and foveate, these foveae deep and scarce on anterior lobe, shallow and more numerous on posterior lobe. Meso- and metathoracic spiracles evident (
Fig. 7
, SpII, SpIII). Intersegmental suture between meso and metathorax laterally distinct (
Fig. 7
). Metepisternal process (Ep) reduced. Pair of slen- der grooves (Ev) visible, leading to metasternal scent orifices (
Fig. 7
, so). Metasternal scent channels obliquely curving backwards from midpoint (
Fig. 8
). Mesosternum with distinct rostral groove (
Fig. 8
, RG). Middle and hind coxae placed laterally (
Fig. 8
); intersegmental suture between mesosternum and metasternum with a shallow channel (
Fig. 8
). Mesosternum and metasternum lacking tubercles (
Fig. 8
).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 7. P. d az a . Thorax, female, lateral view, legs removed. Scale 0.05 mm. (Ep: metepisternal process, Ev: lateral evaporatorium of scent apparatus, PL: pronotal lobe, SO: metasternal scent orifice, SpII, SpIII, meso-and metathoracic spiracles, TI: prothorax).

FIGURE 8. P. d az a . Thorax, female, ventral view, legs of left side removed. Scale 0.025 mm. (Ev: evaporative channel of scent apparatus, RG: rostral groove, SIII: metasternum, S2: abdominal sterna).
FIGURE 9. P. d a z a , male abdominal ventrite VI, transversal view. Scale 0.01 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Length of leg segments as follows: fore femur / tibia / tarsal 1 / tarsal 2 / tarsal 3 : 2.0/ 2.16 / 0.12 / 0.28 / 0.5 ; middle femur / tibia / tarsal 1 / tarsal 2 / tarsal 3 : 2.48 / 2.92 / 0.16 / 0.5 / 0.58 ; hind femur / tibia / tarsal 1 / tarsal 2 / tarsal 3 : 3.46 / 5.20 / 0.18 / 0.80 / 0.70 .

Venter of body lightly convex. Ventral apodeme of abdomen arising from anterior margin of sternum VII and extending forward to sternum V. Proctiger horizontal in relation to body (
Fig. 16
). First gonocoxae large and hairy at apex (
Fig. 17
); second gonocoxae as in
Fig. 18
; second gonapophyses with feathered outgrowths (
Fig. 19
). Gynatrial sac trapezoidal (
Fig. 20
, GS) with numerous thin gland ductules projecting from the external surface of the sac (
Fig. 20
); spermathecal tube (
Fig. 20
, ST) arising from ventral side of gynatrial sac; fecundation canal (
Fig. 20
, FC) short, with a pair of small apodemes basally (
Fig. 20
, ap), and a pair of flattened, slightly sclerotized small strips apically; basal thickening (
Fig. 20
, BT) weakly sclerotized and curved. Grasping comb very short, extending for about 1 / 13 of fore tibia. Tibiae slender, straight, with grooming structures at apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
P. daza
, male proctiger, ventral view. Scale 0.025 mm.
FIGURE 11. P. d az a , male genitalia, lateral view. Scale 0.025 mm.

FIGURE 12.
P. daza
, male genitalia, dorsal view, phallus deflated, proctiger removed. Scale 0.025 mm.

FIGURE 13.
P. daza
, male paramere, flat side of left paramere (left), apex in posterior view (right). Scale 0.05 mm.
FIGURE 14. P. d a z a , fore leg of male with grasping comb, dorsal view, and fore tibia with grooming structure, ventral view. Scale 0.05 mm.
FIGURE 15. P. d a z a , left middle tarsus, only marginal hairs shown. Scale 0.01 mm. (Ca: campaniform sensillum, DA: dorsal arolium, g: grooming structures, h: bristlelike hair, Pe: parempodium).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
Daza , road to Villamoreno, Pasto, Nariño, Colombia (
Fig. 21
).

Ecological notes.
Paravelia daza
sp. n.
is found under stones at the erosional margins of streams. Nymphs (
Fig. 6
) are occasionally found on the surface film at the borders of temporary pools. When discovered under stones, specimens remain still and camouflaged with the substrate. They can remain hidden, or stride on the superficial film very rapidly, and do not move like other veliids or gerrids. Individuals can move easily on the ground, walking or running; and it is probable that the subterminal position of their claws is a secondary adaptation towards a semi-terrestrial way of life, as
Andersen ( 1982 )
suggests for other species of veliids.
Etymology. The name “ daza ” refers to type locality.

Paravelia daza
sp. n.
is similar to
P. inveruglas (Kirkaldy, 1899 )
from Ecuador , but the latter is smaller (length of male 7.25 mm ), and different in morphometric measurements, and in the shape of the male parameres (compare Figs. 13 , 22 ).
